user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of make_blocking:
```c
static void
make_blocking (MHD_socket fd)
{
#if defined(MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS)
  int flags;

  flags = fcntl (fd, F_GETFL);
  if (-1 == flags)
    abort ();
  if ((flags & ~O_NONBLOCK) != flags)
    if (-1 == fcntl (fd, F_SETFL, flags & ~O_NONBLOCK))
      abort ();
#elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  unsigned long flags = 0;

  if (0 != ioctlsocket (fd, (int) FIONBIO, &flags))
    abort ();
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only constructs in this function that can be conditionally excluded from a translation unit (and therefore potentially be unreachable in a given build) are the platform-specific conditional-compilation blocks (#if defined(MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS) / #elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS) / #endif). Each branch is mutually exclusive for a single build configuration, so the branch not selected by the preprocessor will not be present in the compiled translation unit and should be reviewed for possible unreachable-code concerns. Other parts of the function do not present unreachable-code issues: the function header and closing brace are syntactically required; the local declarations and the subsequent calls (fcntl, ioctlsocket) are used within their respective branches; there are no statements following a terminating call (e.g. no code after abort() in the same flow) that would be unconditionally unreachable; and there are no return statements or control-flow constructs in this snippet that produce unreachable statements. Therefore only the conditional compilation blocks need investigation for MISRA Rule 2.1 compliance.
